Preferential oxidation of CO in a hydrogen rich feed stream using Co–Fe mixed metal oxide catalysts prepared from hydrotalcite precursors Lindelani Q. Qwabe Holger B. Friedrich Sooboo Singh ⁎ School of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Private Bag X54001, Durban 4000, South Africa School of Chemistry and Physics University of KwaZulu-Natal Private Bag X54001 Durban 4000 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +27 31 2607017; fax: +27 31 260 3091. Graphical abstract Mixed metal oxide catalysts of Co and Fe in the ratio of 1:1, 2:1 and 3:1 were derived from hydrotalcite-like precursors. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, SEM, HR-TEM, H2-TPR, FTIR and ICP-OES. The solids which were polycrystalline in nature, showed mesoporous character and an average crystallite size of 15nm. Powder XRD of the calcined precursors showed the presence of CoFe2O4 and the surface area of the catalysts ranged between 73 and 83m2/g. H2-TPR studies revealed that the catalyst with a 3:1 Co:Fe ratio had a higher H2 consumption at the peak corresponding to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO when compared to the catalysts with a Co:Fe ratio of 2:1 and 1:1. The catalysts prepared from hydrotalcite-like precursors were more active than the physical mixtures. Furthermore, a catalyst prepared by conventional co-precipitation resembling a ratio of 2:1 was less active than the catalyst of the same metal ratio prepared via hydrotalcite route in the preferential oxidation of CO over the temperature range of 25–180°C. CO conversions of 100% between 120 and 180°C with varied selectivity toward CO2 were obtained at a space velocity of 12,000h−1. Time on stream experiments showed that the catalysts were stable over 24h. The presence of CO2 and H2O in the feed-stream resulted in catalyst deactivation. However, the deactivated catalysts were regenerated when calcined in situ. Keywords Carbon monoxide Hydrogen Preferential oxidation Mixed metal oxides Deactivation 1 Introduction The global demand for energy has increased substantially over the past years. This situation has placed enormous pressure on fossil fuels which have been the major resource for energy generation. The fact that fossil fuels constitute a finite resource and the deleterious impact that their exploitation has on the environment, has been sharply brought into focus, has given rise to an urgency to seek alternative sources of energy which are more environmentally friendly. Recently, fuel cells have attracted attention as a viable alternative to present devices that utilise fossil fuels and they are considered a much cleaner and efficient energy resource. Hydrogen, found in abundance, is used in fuel cells for the on board generation of electricity. Hydrogen is produced by a number of processes, but the most commonly used process is the steam reforming of hydrocarbons [1–4]. However, there are problems associated with hydrogen production from steam reforming because the product stream contains about 0.2–2% CO, together with CO2 and H2. CO is detrimental to fuel cell operation, since it is known to poison the platinum electrodes of the cell [5–10]. Lowering of the levels of CO is essential and is partially addressed by the water gas shift reaction, but decreasing CO concentration to acceptable levels, requires preferential oxidation (CO PROX) [11,12]. Research on CO PROX show that most work involves the use of precious metal based catalysts which invariably utilise gold and platinum [4,13]. Even though gold is popular because of its ability to oxidize CO even at ambient temperatures when dispersed as nanoparticles on oxide supports, the price of this precious metal is of concern. Also, selectivity towards CO2 on gold catalysts is usually poor when compared to transition metal oxides that are active for CO PROX [3,5,7]. There is, therefore, a need for the development of efficient and selective catalysts that exclude these precious metals. Metal oxide catalysts have received considerable attention in the recent past and, among them, Co3O4 and CuO have been the most extensively studied and show good activity for CO PROX [5–7,9,10,12,14]. They have been used as single oxides or supported on other oxides such as CeO2, ZrO2, Ce x Zr1-x O2, or as mixed metal oxides, such as Co3O4– CuO and Co3O4– CeO2, [10,12,15–21]. Co3O4 catalysts have shown superior low temperature CO activity, CO2 selectivity and resistance to H2O selectivity compared to CuO catalysts [10] and, to date, are still widely studied for CO oxidation in the absence of H2 [22–25]. Recently, cobalt oxides supported on ceria and zicornia were shown to be promising catalysts for CO-PROX [12,16,20]. Gawade et al. [16] showed that the increase in cobalt loading favoured CO conversion in CO-PROX. It was noted that this behavior was only applicable at temperatures below 150°C. Time on stream experiments in this study showed that the catalysts exhibited good stability, suggesting that no reduction occurred even in the presence of H2 which was a concern in previous studies conducted, where reduction of cobalt to lower oxidation states (including metallic cobalt) promoted undesirable side reactions in CO-PROX [9,12]. Zhao et al. [10] reported on a 16wt% Co3O4 catalyst supported on Ce x Zr1-x O2 for CO PROX in the 25–250°C temperature range. They obtained CO conversion of almost 100% and selectivity of about 70% at 125°C. However, the introduction of H2O and CO2 decreased the activity and required an increase in the temperature for complete CO conversion. This catalyst exhibited good stability in the presence CO2 and H2O, suggesting that reduction of cobalt to lower oxidation states also did not occur during time on stream. In this study, we prepared Co–Fe mixed metal oxides from hydrotalcite-like precursors and investigated their activity in a simulated reformate feed stream. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Mixed metal oxide catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation using the method described by Rives et al. [26]. In a typical synthesis of a hydrotalcite-like material containing Co:Fe in the ratio of 2:1, 50.0g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 34.70g of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 200mL of double distilled water. The metal solution was added drop-wise to a beaker containing a 200mL solution of 40.6g of Na2CO3·10H2O· NaOH was added when required, to maintain the pH of the solution between 8 and 10. The resulting precipitate was transferred to a round bottom flask, heated to 100°C and maintained at this temperature under reflux for 18h. The precipitate was then filtered and washed thoroughly with double distilled water until the filtrate had a pH of 7. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 110°C overnight and calcined in a steady flow of air at 450°C for 2h. The catalysts were labelled according to their metal ratio, i.e., Co–Fe HTLc refers to the hydrotalcite-like sample with Co:Fe ratio of 1:1 and Co–Fe, its calcined form, whereas 2Co–Fe HTLc and 3Co–Fe HTLc refers to hydrotalcite-like samples with Co:Fe ratio of 2:1 and 3:1 and their calcined form, 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe, respectively. The calcined form of the catalyst precursor prepared via conventional co-precipitation is denoted 2Co–Fe (Cop). 2.2 Catalyst characterisation Elemental composition was obtained by ICP-OES using a PerkinElmer Optima 5300 DV spectrometer. Standards (1000ppm Co and Fe) were purchased from Fluka. Surface area measurements were performed by nitrogen adsorption at −196°C using the BET method. Samples weighing approximately 0.1g were degassed at 200°C under vacuum overnight and were analysed in a Micromeritics Tristar II instrument. The diffraction patterns of all samples were obtained using a Bruker D8 Instrument operating on CuKα radiation source with wavelength, λ =1.54056 Ǻ, generated at 40kV and 40mA. Signals were recorded for 2θ values between 5° and 90°. Thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis were carried out in a SDT Q600 thermal analyser in static air atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images were captured on a JEOL JEM 1010 and JEOL JEM 2100 instruments equipped with tungsten and LaB6 filaments, respectively. The X-rays emitted from samples upon electron impact were collected in the 0–20 keV range. Field emission scanning electron microscope images (FE-SEM) were acquired on a ZEISS FE-SEM Ultra Plus instrument. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was carried out using a Micromeritics 2920 Autochem II Chemisorption Analyser. Prior to the reduction of the sample in TPR, the catalyst was pretreated by heating under a stream of argon (30–cm3/min) at 400°C for 30min and then cooled to 80°C. Thereafter, 5% hydrogen in argon was used as a reducing agent at a flow rate of 30mL/min. Under these conditions the temperature was ramped up to 950°C. FT-IR (ATR) studies were conducted on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 equipped with a diamond crystal scanning from 300 to 4000cm−1. 2.3 Catalyst testing Catalytic testing was done in a custom made test unit housing two reactors, each with an internal diameter of 18mm and 500mm in length. The tubular reactors were enclosed within a four zone metal block possessing high thermal conductivity and were controlled with their own digital temperature controller. The unit is interfaced with an online three channel Varian 490 Micro GC, equipped with Galaxie Software. The first channel contains a molecular sieve 5A PLOT (10m) standard injector, equipped with back flush facility for removal of gases like CO2. The other two channels are equipped with CP-Sil 5CB (10m) and heated injectors. The feed mixture, containing 1% CO, 1 or 2% O2, 50% H2 and the balance, N2 was introduced into the reactors using Brooks mass flow controllers. In cases where the effect of CO2 was evaluated, 10% and 15% CO2 were used as part of the feed where necessary, whereas in the experiments to evaluate the effect of moisture, the feed was passed through a water reservoir using a bubbler at a controlled temperature to give 8.8% H2O. The total gas flow rates were either 20mLmin−1 or 40mLmin−1, to obtain a GHSV of 12,000h−1 or 24,000h−1, respectively. All catalysts were diluted with SiC to obtain a catalyst volume of 3mL and were pre-treated with N2 at 150°C for 2h in order to remove surface moisture and cooled down to room temperature before reactions were carried out. The conversion and selectivity were calculated as follows: CO conversion = CO i n − CO out CO in × 100 % CO 2 selectivity = CO in − CO out 2 ( O 2 in − O 2 out ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation of catalysts 3.1.1 Powder X-ray diffraction The XRD diffractograms of the hydrotalcite precursors (Fig. 1 ) show peaks that are generally broad and small indicating poor crystallinity and small crystal structure. However, the formation of the hydrotalcite-like structure was evident. The first three peaks at lower 2θ values result from diffractions corresponding to planes (003), (006) and (009), while the doublet at 2θ =60° result corresponds to planes, (110) and (113). These are considered to be signature peaks for a hydrotalcite-like materials and are in agreement with literature reported previously [26,27]. The catalyst prepare via conventional co-precipitation did not show peaks indicating a different structure (amorphous) from the other three hydrotalcite-like precursors. After calcination, all catalysts including the 2Co–Fe (Cop) formed mixed oxides which exhibited characteristic peaks that can be indexed to the Co3O4 phase [10,28], a spinel CoFe2O4 phase and Fe2O3 [28]. The samples exhibited a low degree of crystallinity. The average crystallite sizes for the samples estimated from the Scherer equation using the main diffraction peaks of the spinel CoFe2O4 (311) were between 13 and 18nm for Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe. The crystallite size estimated for 2Co–Fe (Cop) sample was slightly larger than the rest of samples. 3.1.2 Electron microscopy The TEM and SEM images of hydrotalcite-like precursors are shown in Fig. 2 . The images show hexagonal platelet like morphology that confirm the formation of the hydrotalcite-like layers [26]. The metal distribution and percentage of each sample shown by EDX of both samples is in agreement with ICP results. Fig. 3 shows the high magnification and diffraction patterns of both oxides. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern suggests that the oxides are polycrystalline, which is supported by low peak intensities obtained in the XRD diffactograms [29]. 3.1.3 BET surface area and elemental analysis Table 1 shows a summary of the textural properties of the catalysts. As reported in literature [27,30], a proportional relationship between surface area and pore volume exists. Surface area for both catalysts decreased with decreasing pore volume after calcination, but pore size increased. The decrease in the surface is due to the collapse of the hydrotalcite structure after calcination. The decrease in pore volume is related to the agglomeration of pores as temperature increases [30]. The increase in pore size after calcination may be attributed to the release of entrapped water molecules and carbonates [26,31,32] leading to a complete structural change of the material. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe are shown in Fig. 4 (a) and are classified as type II isotherms. This type of isotherm is indicative of the existence of mesoporous structures. The hysteresis loop in both samples is narrow and corresponds to a type H3, typical of solids consisting of agglomerates of particles, forming slit-like mesopores open at both ends [27,28]. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of 2Co–Fe (Cop) can be classified as a type IV isotherm consisting of an H2 hysteresis loop according to IUPAC classification, indicating a complex mesoporous structure [28]. The pore size distribution (Fig. 4(b)), determined by the BJH method reveals narrow peaks centred between 6–10nm, suggesting uniformity of pores for Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe. The pore size distribution for 2Co–Fe (Cop) is slightly broader when compared to samples prepared via hydrotalcite route and is centred at around 18nm. 3.1.4 Thermal effects Fig. 5 shows that the TGA and DTA profiles for the samples are similar. There are essentially two transitions indicating mass losses, one at about 125°C and the other from around 130–400°C for Co–Fe HTLc, 2Co–Fe HTLc and 2Co–Fe (Cop) precursor samples. The first mass loss at about 125°C corresponds to an endothermic peak and is probably due to the removal of adsorbed water molecules. The second mass loss is weak and probably due to removal of interlayer water, hydroxylation, evolution of CO2 and decomposition of iron and cobalt nitrate to amorphous iron and cobalt oxides [21,39]. There are two weak endothermic peaks at about 225°C and 325°C. When the sample is calcined, Co2+ is oxidized to Co3+ (an exothermic process) in the same temperature range as that of removal of water, CO2 and dehydroxylation, which are endothermic processes [28,33]. The exothermic and endothermic processes, therefore, cancel each other out, explaining the presence of the two weak endothermic peaks. The 3Co–Fe HTLc sample, however, exhibited three mass loses, one at about 125° and the other two in the 130–400°C region. The first mass loss in the 130–400°C region can be attributed to loss of water from the interlayer and dehydroxylation. The final mass loss is probably due decarboxylation and decomposition of iron and cobalt nitrate to amorphous iron and cobalt oxides as discussed earlier. These mass losses are accompanied by corresponding endothermic peaks. 3.1.5 Temperature programmed reduction Fig. 6 (a–c) displays the H2-TPR profiles of Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe, respectively. The profiles are similar, but differ in hydrogen consumption, indicating differences in the quantities of the oxides in the catalysts. Analysis of the profiles, reveals four reduction peaks after de-convolution. These reduction peaks are due to the following reduction reactions [28]: C O 3 O 4 → ∼ 340 ° C C o O → ∼ 570 ° C C o F e 2 O 3 → ∼ 410 ° C F e 3 O 4 → ∼ 720 ° C F e The small peak at about 340°C is attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and the hydrogen consumption at this temperature was 9.27, 10.1 and 40.1mL/g for Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe, respectively. This is consistent with increasing cobalt content in the samples. This peak was expected at around 280°C as reported by Biabani-Ravandi et al. [29] and Del Arco et al. [33], but the shift of this peak to about 340°C is probably due to the strong interaction of Co and Fe and also the presence of CoFe2O4. The broad peaks with a small shoulder at about 430°C in Co–Fe and 2Co–Fe indicates three reduction steps. Initially, Fe2O3 is reduced to Fe3O4 at about 410°C, then CoO is reduced to Co0 at about 570°C and finally, Fe3O4 is reduced to Fe0 at about 720°C [28,29]. The hydrogen consumption recorded at about 410°C was 51, 18 and 10.2mL/g for Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe, respectively. The decrease in hydrogen consumption is consistent with decreasing iron content. At about 570°C, the hydrogen consumption recorded were 112, 132 and 194mL/g for Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe, respectively, which is in agreement with increasing cobalt content. Finally, at about 720°C, hydrogen consumption recorded was 37, 91 and 75.9mL/g for Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe, 3Co–Fe, respectively. The discrepancy in hydrogen consumption at 720°C for the 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe catalysts is probably due to the overlapping reduction temperatures of CoO to Co and Fe3O4 to Fe. The TPR profile of 2Co–Fe (Cop) catalyst was similar to that of 2Co–Fe but higher hydrogen consumptions were recorded, suggesting that the sample was more difficult to reduce (Fig. 6(d)). 3.1.6 Fourier transformed infra-red spectroscopy Fig. 7 shows the FTIR spectra of Co–Fe, 2Co–Fe, 3Co–Fe and 2Co–Fe (Cop). The broad absorption bands observed at around 3371 and 3349, 1641 and 1635cm−1 for all samples are due to the OH stretching vibrations from surface adsorbed water molecules and hydroxyl groups [34,35]. The bands at around 934cm−1 in the samples are characteristic of the cobalt ferrite systems and could be due to FeO–OH [35]. The bands at around 540, 623 and 640cm−1 could be assigned to v (Co–O) modes typical of Co3O4, whereas the bands around 540 and 490cm−1 could be related to Fe2O3 [34]. 3.2 Catalytic testing 3.2.1 Preferential CO oxidation Preferential CO oxidation (CO PROX) reactions were carried out in the temperature range of 25–180°C with the GHSV fixed at 12,000h−1 and 24,000h−1, respectively. A reformate gas mixture comprising 1% CO, 1 and 2% O2, 50% H2 and the balance, N2, was used for catalyst testing for CO PROX. Initial testing commenced using physical mixtures of Co and Fe oxides and the performance of these catalysts were compared to that of the mixed oxides prepared via the hydrotalcite route. From Fig. 8 , the oxides prepared via the hydrotalcite route were more active than the physical mixtures. Furthermore, a catalyst prepared via conventional co-precipitation method, 2Co–Fe (Cop), resembling, 2Co–Fe was tested at 12,000h−1 and 1% O2 and compared to the catalysts prepared via the hydrotalcite route. From Fig. 9 , it is observed that 2Co–Fe (Cop) is less active, correlating with TPR results. The oxides with more cobalt were more efficient in catalysing CO to CO2, as shown also by previous studies that the mixed oxidation state of cobalt in Co3O4 and cobalt concentration influences the conversion and selectivity towards CO2 [11,15,19,20]. This could be the result of the high reducibility of 2Co–Fe and 3Co–Fe as shown by TPR. 3Co–Fe appears to be less active than 2Co–Fe at temperatures below 100°C but reaches complete CO conversion at the same temperature as 2Co–Fe. The selectivity of this catalyst is much lower than 2Co–Fe at temperatures exceeding 100°C. Fig. 10 displays the conversion and selectivity of the Co–Fe and 2Co–Fe catalysts at varying GHSV and CO:O2 ratios. The catalysts were active from room temperature, but complete conversion of CO over the 2Co–Fe catalyst was obtained at 150°C for both space velocities at a CO:O2 ratio of 1:1. For the Co–Fe catalyst, complete conversion occurred at 180°C under the same conditions and the selectivity towards CO2 was almost similar. When the oxygen concentration was increased, an improvement in the conversion was obtained. The textural studies of the catalysts reveal the presence of mesopores accompanied by a large surface area. Materials with uniform mesoporosity have been reported by Cao et al. [34] to enhance catalytic activity of the catalysts which is consistent with high activity observed on our catalysts. The decrease in CO conversion with increase in GHSV is due to shorter residence time of CO over the catalysts. 3.2.2 Time on stream experiments Fig. 11 (a) and (b) show the effect of time for both catalysts at 120°C and 180°C at 12,000h−1. The catalysts show consistent, almost complete conversion of CO at 180°C, but at 120°C, there was a steady decrease in the conversion over time. The selectivity towards CO2 at 120°C was similar for both the catalysts, but at 180°C it decreased by about 20%. The decrease in the selectivity to CO2 was accompanied by an increase in the formation of water. There are different views that are put forward to explain the decrease in conversion over time for CO PROX. These include a single or combination of factors, such as blocking of active sites by water [10,36], the formation of an inactive CO–H2O complex [16,37], accumulation of carbonates on the active sites of the catalyst [10,38], the reduction of the Co3+ in the Co3O4 phase [12,16] or the competitive adsorption between CO and CO2 on the active sites of the catalyst [21,38]. To understand the reason for a decrease in the conversion at 120°C over time, an experiment was carried out where 10vol.% CO2 was co–fed with CO. Fig. 12 shows the effect of the addition of the CO2. There was a steady decrease in the conversion over both catalysts over time and conversion decreased by about 40% after 10h. A partial recovery of the activity of the catalysts was noted within the first hour after CO2 was removed, indicating that the competitive nature of CO2 adsorption coupled with the accumulation of carbonate species on the active sites could be responsible for the loss of activity. When these catalysts were calcined, in situ under air at 270°C overnight and examined for time on stream experiments for another 24h, the conversions obtained were similar to those of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 13 ). Since the catalysts showed excellent recovery, it is evident that calcining the catalyst removed adsorbed CO2 and carbonate species from the surface of the catalyst. The selectivity towards CO2 for both the catalysts improved slightly during deactivation, but decreased and showed trends of the fresh catalyst after calcination, indicating that CO2 could have adsorbed on the active sites for CO oxidation. A comparison of the results for CO PROX with literature is shown in Table 2 . 3.2.3 Addition of CO2 and H2O When the catalysts were tested with 15vol.% CO2 at 180°C, the conversion decreased by about 10%, but stabilised after 6h. Results are shown in Figs. 14 and 15 , . The decrease in CO conversion could be attributed be the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) [16], in addition to competitive adsorption, formation of carbonate species and the blockage of sites by the CO–H2O complex. The RWGS reaction promotes the formation of CO through the reduction of CO2 by hydrogen at high temperatures. However, conducting the RWGS reaction with 50% H2 and 1% CO2 and balance N2 at 180°C did not produce CO, indicating that at this temperature this reaction did not occur. Also, there was no substantial H2 and CO2 conversion during the reaction in the presence of CO2. It is also reported that at temperatures higher than 200°C, the methanation reaction is instead favoured over RWGS. In a separate experiment, where water was added to the feed, there was a steady decrease in the conversion, but an improvement in the selectivity towards CO2. This was accompanied by a decrease in hydrogen and oxygen conversions. Deactivation in this case is probably due to H2O blocking the active sites of the catalysts and forming the unreactive CO–H2O complex [15,16,21,22]. Finally, the catalysts were tested in the presence of both 8.8vol.% H2O and 15vol.% CO2. Both catalysts deactivated much faster than in the presence of either CO2 or H2O alone. The CO conversion over the 2Co–Fe catalyst decreased from 90% to 58% after 16h, whereas it decreased from 80% to 34% over Co–Fe for the same duration. This could be due to a combination of the competitive adsorption between CO and CO2 and blocking of active sites on the catalyst surface by H2O [16,21]. In addition, the formation of a CO–H2O complex formation could also be contributing to the deactivation of the catalysts. 4 Conclusion Mixed metal oxides that were prepared from hydrotalcite-like precursors were more active for CO PROX within the desired temperature range compared to their equivalent physical mixtures. The 2Co–Fe catalyst was more active than Co–Fe because of the presence of more of the Co3O4 phase. Time on stream experiments conducted at two temperatures showed that catalyst deactivation occurred at the lower temperature. Deactivation was reversed when these catalysts were subjected to heat treatment under a flow of air. The conversion decreased when CO2 was included in the feed. However, the subsequent removal of CO2 from the feed resulted in an improvement in the conversion, but lower than the conversions obtained for the fresh catalysts. The addition of water resulted in a steady decrease in the conversion, but an improvement in the selectivity towards CO2 accompanied by a decrease in hydrogen and oxygen conversions. The addition of CO2 and H2O resulted in the deactivation of the catalysts at a much faster rate. coredata.dc:description: Mixed metal oxide catalysts of Co and Fe in the ratio of 1:1, 2:1 and 3:1 were derived from hydrotalcite-like precursors. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, SEM, HR-TEM, H2-TPR, FTIR and ICP-OES. The solids which were polycrystalline in nature, showed mesoporous character and an average crystallite size of 15nm. Powder XRD of the calcined precursors showed the presence of CoFe2O4 and the surface area of the catalysts ranged between 73 and 83m2/g. H2-TPR studies revealed that the catalyst with a 3:1 Co:Fe ratio had a higher H2 consumption at the peak corresponding to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO when compared to the catalysts with a Co:Fe ratio of 2:1 and 1:1. The catalysts prepared from hydrotalcite-like precursors were more active than the physical mixtures. Furthermore, a catalyst prepared by conventional co-precipitation resembling a ratio of 2:1 was less active than the catalyst of the same metal ratio prepared via hydrotalcite route in the preferential oxidation of CO over the temperature range of 25–180°C. CO conversions of 100% between 120 and 180°C with varied selectivity toward CO2 were obtained at a space velocity of 12,000h−1. Time on stream experiments showed that the catalysts were stable over 24h. The presence of CO2 and H2O in the feed-stream resulted in catalyst deactivation. However, the deactivated catalysts were regenerated when calcined in situ.
coredata.dc:title: Preferential oxidation of CO in a hydrogen rich feed stream using Co–Fe mixed metal oxide catalysts prepared from hydrotalcite precursors
